Conditioned Place Preference is a way of finding out what animals want. Researchers train them to associate one place with an experience such as food or a loud noise and another place with something completely ① [ different / similar ], usually where nothing happens. Conversely, if it now avoids the place the stimulus appeared and starts to prefer the place it did not experience it, then this suggests that it found the stimulus ⑤ [ unpleasant / pleasant ]. For example, mice with cancer show a preference for the place where they have been given morphine, a drug used to ⑥ [ relieve / cause ] pain, rather than where they have received saline, whereas healthy mice developed no such preference. This suggests that the mice with cancer ⑦ [ rejected / l wanted ] the morphine, while the healthy mice may have ⑧ [ ignored / desired ] it.

In ⑧ [ cold / warm ] regions, however, songbirds may raise several families in a few months. In an exceptionally ⑨ [ bad / good ] year, a pair of House Sparrows, a kind of songbird, can raise successive broods through a marathon ⑩ [ underproductive / reproductive ] effort.

All translators feel some ① [ relief / pressure ] from the community of readers for whom they are doing their work. And all translators arrive at their ② [ misinterpretations / interpretations ] in ③ [ silence / dialogue ] with other people. Even when the scene of translation consists of just one person with a pen, paper, and the book that is being translated, or even when it is just one person translating orally for another, that person's linguistic knowledge arises from lots of other texts and other conversations. And then his or her idea of the translation's purpose will be ⑤ [ influenced / independent ] by the ⑥ [ disappointments / expectations ] of the person or people it is for. In both these senses, every translation is a crowd translation.

Thus, it is worth attempting to collect together these ④ [ ordinary / exceptional ] forms of reading into a single forum, one highlighting the challenges faced by anyone wishing to establish the boundaries where reading begins and ends. The attempt moves toward an understanding of reading as a ⑤ [ spectrum / fixed point ] that is expansive enough to accommodate the ⑥ [ general / distinct ] reading activities.

Weber's law concerns the perception of difference between two stimuli. It suggests that we might not be able to ① [ ignore / detect ] a 1-mm difference when we are looking at lines 466 mm and 467 mm in length, but we may be able to ② [ overlook / notice ] a 1-mm difference when we are comparing a line 2 mm long with one 3 mm long. But when 1 candle is lit in a room in which 100 candles are already burning, we may not ④ [ notice / overlook ] the light from this candle. For example, the JND is greater for very ⑤ [ quiet / loud ] noises than it is for much more ⑥ [ loud / quiet ] sounds. When a sound is very ⑦ [ weak / strong ], we can tell that another sound is ⑧ [ louder / quieter ], even if it is barely ⑨ [ louder / quieter ]. When a sound is very ⑩ [ loud / quiet ], to tell that another sound is even ⑪ [ quieter / louder ], it has to be much ⑫ [ quieter / louder ]. Thus, Weber's law means that it is harder to ⑬ [ confuse / distinguish ] between two samples when those samples are larger or stronger levels of the stimuli.

Another example of this principle is that we can ③ [ detect / ignore ] 1 candle when it is lit in an otherwise dark room. But when 1 candle is lit in a room in which 100 candles are already burning, we may not ④ [ notice / overlook ] the light from this candle. Therefore, the Just-noticeable difference (JND) varies as a function of the strength of the signals. For example, the JND is greater for very ⑤ [ quiet / loud ] noises than it is for much more ⑥ [ loud / quiet ] sounds. When a sound is very ⑦ [ weak / strong ], we can tell that another sound is ⑧ [ louder / quieter ], even if it is barely ⑨ [ louder / quieter ]. When a sound is very ⑩ [ loud / quiet ], to tell that another sound is even ⑪ [ quieter / louder ], it has to be much ⑫ [ quieter / louder ]. Thus, Weber's law means that it is harder to ⑬ [ confuse / distinguish ] between two samples when those samples are larger or stronger levels of the stimuli.

Traffic jams, ④ [ overcrowding / spaciousness ], and overuse ⑤ [ enhance / lessen ] the benefits of the common resource for everyone - the tragedy of the commons! The total activity on this new resource keeps ⑦ [ increasing / decreasing ], and so does individual activity; but if the dynamic of common use and overuse continues too long, both begin to ⑧ [ rise / fall ] after a peak, leading to a ⑨ [ crash / recovery ]. According to Hobbes, man is not a being who can act morally in spite of his instinct to protect his existence in the state of nature. Hence, the only place where morality and moral liberty will begin to find an application begins in a place where a sovereign power, namely the state, emerges. In other words, Hobbes, who accepted that human beings are not social and political beings in the state of nature, believes that without the power human beings in the state of nature are ⑦ [ social / antisocial ] and ⑧ [ irrational / rational ] based on their selfishness. Moreover, since society is not a natural phenomenon and there is no natural force bringing people together, what will bring them together as a society is not mutual affection according to Hobbes. It is, rather, mutual ⑨ [ trust / fear ] of men's present and future that assembles them, since the cause of fear is a common drive among people in the state of nature.
